Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Single Crystal X-Ray Diffractometer
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program (MRI) and support from the Chemistry Research Instrumentation Program (CRIF), Professor Robert Houser from the University of Northern Colorado and colleagues Robin Macaluso and Michael Mosher will acquire an X-ray diffractometer. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here will impact a number of areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument will be an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of chemistry and physics students as well as high school teachers.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) exploring rare-earth magnetic intermetallic compounds; (b) investigating the redox chemistry of thioether amide ligands with copper(II); (c) developing G-quadruplex ligands; (d) synthesizing and characterizing non-traditional semiconductor thermoelectric and photovoltaic materials; and (e) detecting fluorescence of biomolecules.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from the National Science Foundation MRI program allowed for the acquisition of a Bruker D8 QUEST single crystal X-ray diffractometer (XRD) at the University of Northern Colorado (UNCO). The XRD instrument is equipped with a Mo sealed X-ray tube, a Haskris LX2 air cooled chiller, and the Oxford 700 low temperature device. Since installation was completed in March 2015, experiments carried out have supported the research of three research groups at UNCO, and one research group at the Colorado School of Mines. Results have been reported through journal publications, seminars and presentations at regional and national meetings.

The addition of a single-crystal XRD has provided data critical to the advancement of research in a variety of research areas: synthesis of transition metal, bioinorganic, organic, and photovoltaic and thermoelectric compounds and materials. Undergraduate, graduate, postdoctoral researchers and faculty benefited from hands-on experience with the single-crystal XRD. The instrument was integrated into undergraduate laboratory and graduate-level courses. The senior-level inorganic chemistry course, Chem 433, incorporated a new laboratory module that focused on single-crystal X-ray crystallography. Students are given classroom instruction on crystallography, including a pre-lab homework project. This is followed by a 3-4 hour hands-on demonstration of the instrument including crystallization techniques, selecting and mounting crystals, data collection, and structure solution.
